Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Evaluating the role of thyroid hormone in embryonic limb development in direct-developing frogs
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study will clarify the role of thyroid hormone in the development of amphibian limbs. Hormones are substances produced in the body that influences the way the body grows or develops. Thyroid hormone plays an important role in the transition of tadpoles into frogs, especially in limb development. Nearly a third of frog species bypass the tadpole stage and develop directly into frogs and the role of thyroid hormone in the development of these species is not known. This project will test two alternative hypotheses about the role of thyroid hormone in this process. In association with the Harvard Museum of Natural History, this project will also develop several educational activities on amphibian biodiversity for K-12 students, teachers, and parents. Some of these activities can be offered at little cost, which will allow many students to experience wildlife and witness the dramatic transformation of metamorphosis for themselves.

Comparing how thyroid hormone regulates gene activity during limb development between direct-developing and metamorphosing frogs can tell us how fundamental endocrine networks evolve and generate different life cycles. Biphasic frogs (which undergo metamorphosis) require thyroid hormone (TH) for metamorphosis and limb development. This study evaluates the role of TH in limb development in the direct-developing frog Eleutherodactylus coqui for comparison to its role in three biphasic frog taxa (Xenopus laevis, Bombina orientalis, and Dendrobates tinctorius). Next-generation sequencing will be used to characterize and compare the TH-induced molecular phenotype in the developing limb of all four species. This study will provide a basis for further studies of amphibian life history evolution and identify interspecific variation in an otherwise highly conserved molecular mechanism of metamorphosis. Characterizing how one group achieves direct development will provide a comparison for investigating the repeated origins of this life history in other amphibians, and address questions at the intersection of endocrinology, evolution, and development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hormones have powerful and long-lasting effects on animal biology. Endocrine systems, which secrete hormonal signals, have deep evolutionary roots and share common components across the animal kingdom. Comparing endocrine systems among different animal species can help us understand both how mechanisms of hormonal regulation have evolved and what happens when these systems break, as is the case with many human diseases. Amphibians, and frogs in particular, are excellent models for studying evolutionary endocrinology. While most frogs go through a dramatic and hormonally controlled metamorphosis after hatching, this life history is heavily modified in many other living species. One such modification, called direct development, involves the complete absence of the free-living aquatic tadpole stage. Direct-developing frogs develop adult features, including limbs, inside the egg and hatch as miniature adults.

Thyroid hormone (TH) promotes limb development during the post-embryonic metamorphosis that is characteristic of most frogs. In contrast, limbs form before hatching--indeed, prior to formation of the embryo's own thyroid gland--in direct-developing frogs. Hence, it has long been believed that changes in TH signaling might, in part, underlie the evolution of direct development. My project aimed to understand the role of thyroid hormone in limb development in one species of direct-developing frog, Eleutherodactylus coqui, which is native to Puerto Rico. Specifically, I sought to describe how the expression of TH-signaling genes change over time in the developing limbs of E. coqui and how those gene-expression patterns differ from those in developing limbs of metamorphosing frogs.

My results suggest that major developmental processes in the developing limb, including TH signaling, are largely the same in direct-developing and metamorphosing frogs, although they differ in relative timing between the two life histories. Some TH signaling genes have different expression patterns in E. coqui compared to metamorphosing frogs and deserve further investigation. The endocrine system is pleiotropic; that is, it affects the body in many and diverse ways. As a result, parts of the endocrine system can be altered and cause dramatic changes (such as early limb development) without disrupting other features that are mediated by it. These results also provide additional evidence that, despite the tremendous variation in size and shape of limbs in vertebrates, mechanisms of limb development are highly conserved and modular in nature. 

Additional experiments revealed that early embryos of E. coqui are not insensitive to TH, as was claimed in previous studies. Instead treating embryos with TH was ineffective because the hormone does not readily penetrate the skin. (In the previous studies, TH was applied to embryos simply by adding it to the surrounding liquid rearing medium.) Expression patterns of several TH-signaling genes in the limb of metamorphosing frogs also do not match those of prior studies. Overall, these results serve as a warning that experimental manipulations may not always provide accurate models for analyzing normal development.

There is enormous disparity among American middle-school students with respect to self-confidence in their science process skills and in their access to quality STEM programs. My project offered me the opportunity to develop a lesson plan for middle school students that would enhance their knowledge of evolutionary biology; their understanding of how one can access and learn from museum specimens; and, finally, their skills at empirical observation and scientific inference. Preserved frog specimens from the Museum of Comparative Zoology (MCZ) were digitally scanned, and those scans were used to make lifelike plastic models from a 3D printer. Several sets of models for the lesson plans are housed at the MCZ and are available for loan to teachers. The files are also available for downloading from the museum's website for free for any teacher who wants to print their own models, in addition to several videos that provide helpful background information and the lesson plan. The lesson describes the primary components of evolution by natural selection using physical adaptations of frogs and asks students to make inferences about environments based on these adaptations. Then, the lesson describes how adaptations can be behavioral or developmental and uses this project as an example. Teachers require very little advance preparation in order to deploy the lesson in their classrooms and, because the lesson is modular, teachers can easily modify the lesson for their students as they see fit. In addition to the MCZ, the lesson plan was developed in collaboration with the education department of the Harvard Museum of Natural History, and it was field-tested at several middle schools in Boston and Cambridge, Massachusetts.
